title: Holby City review with spoilers: Ric fights for his life in dreamlike episode, and Lofty discovers he’s going to be a dad
text:
Back in the real world (Picture: BBC)

Holby City gave us a very different kind of episode tonight as we found ourselves accompanying Ric Griffin (Hugh Quarshie) into an alternative reality. As Max McGerry (Jo Martin) and Serena Campbell (Catherine Russell) operated on him (not without drama in itself), Ric apparently woke up in a version of Holby City hospital where he met some people who’d been hugely important to him. Some dead people.

So was this heaven? Diane Lloyd (Patricia Potter) and Ric’s son Leo (Daon Broni) – now CEO and consultant surgeon respectively – didn’t seem to quite know what it was, despite living there. ‘Leo – you’re dead,’ Ric said as he came face to face with his late son. ‘I hate to break this to you, Dad, but so are you,’ Leo replied. When Diane told Ric she was married (we never found out who she was married to), she joked, ‘This is Paradise, after all.’

This dark humour was a thread throughout the dreamlike sequences. Ric protested that he wasn’t in Paradise, and the whole things was ‘a manifestation of my subconscious brought on by exposure to heavy sedatives and severe trauma.’ ‘You say potato,’ Diane said drily. Leo and Diane told Ric there was nothing wrong with his brain – it was his heart that was the problem, because it was ‘empty and rotten’ It needed replacing. Naturally Ric was alarmed to hear this and wanted a second opinion, so who better that Jac Naylor (Rosie Marcel)?

Only the Jac Naylor in this alternate reality was a hippy-dippy ‘Wellness Advisor.’ ‘Do you need help with emotional harmony?’ she asked Ric, and it looked like Rosie Marcel was enjoying herself enormously. Hippy Jac still gave Ric a completely Jac-like view of who he was, though: ‘You’re Leo Griffin’s deadbeat emotionally distant gambling addict absentee father.’

That, in a nutshell, was why he was there. It was all about Ric’s subconscious dealing with things that had always bothered him, the deaths of two people he’d loved deeply and that he felt he’d failed. Hope and the future were represented by great-granddaughter Erica (Leah Mondesir-Simmonds), now an older child though poignantly we and Ric could still hear her baby cries in the background. After he’d made some sort of peace with Diane and been forgiven by Leo, it was Erica who gently but insistently led him to the exit door, back to life – where Serena was waiting for him to wake up.

She’ll help with your emotional harmony (Picture: BBC)

There was so much going on in this episode that I couldn’t possibly mention everything. Long-time Holby viewers were given lots of little Easter eggs including a portrait of Michael Spence (Hari Dhillon) that hung on the corridor wall, a ward named after Zubin Khan and the information that Donna (Jaye Jacobs) was now still married to Kieran, Connie Beauchamp was the Health Secretary, Serena’s daughter Elinor was still alive and so was Bernie. Serena and Bernie were still together.

It was all very dramatic and gothic and sometimes strayed a little too far towards parody, such as when Diane told Ric, ‘Your presence here is destabilising’ and Leo added, ‘Your coming here has opened a rift,’ but it was hugely entertaining and brilliantly connected to the real-life scenes in the operating theatre as Max and Serena battled to keep Ric alive.

Dominic gets a surprise (Picture: BBC)

In complete contrast there was another storyline playing out which was set in the business-as-usual world of Keller. Helen (Verity Marshall), pregnant with Lofty (Lee Mead)’s baby, was back on the ward after a road accident. Dominic (David Ames) had planned to surprise Lofty with a cruise to Hawaii, so he asked Lofty to come up to Keller at 12.30. When Lofty arrived he was greeted by hula dancers and Hawaiian music (Dom is never subtle) – and Helen. Now Lofty knows that he’s going to be a dad, and he knows Dominic’s known for a while, so once again Dofty are on a rocky footing with each other. Lofty questioned whether he and Dom were really working as a couple, and Dominic insisted that they could all make it work – as a family.

It’s times like this that Holby could really do with a resident Wellness Advisor.

Sue Haasler is the author of five novels and the official BBC Holby City book, which you can read about here.
